p.s: In the following I will analyse how strucuture and language support the speaker's idea of love.
Sonnet 116 is written in the typical Shakespearean form with 3 quartrainsquatrains and 1 final couplet.
The raimrhyme scheme is ababcdcdefefgg.

The whole sonnet is a climax because first he says that love can notcannot change because of alteration then he says that love is constant and doesn't change it direction and finalyfinally he says that love doesn't change until death.
So the quartrainsquatrains are based on each other and the right effect is only given when you read them in the correct order.
In line 1 there is a metaphor wichwhich says marriage of true minds, it underlines that the speaker doesn't want to marry because he has to but because he loves the person he wants to marry.
And that you have to be sure about your marriage.
FuthermoreFurthermore there is a comparismcomparison in line 5 which underlines the steadfastness of love and that love leads the lovers the way they want to go.
Love navigates their life.
In the following lines there are two metaphors which are also personifications.
The one metaphor (l. 6), shows how unshakeable love is and that it gets through every fight between the lovers.
So even in hard times love is steadfast and helps you to get over it.
In the metaphor (l. 7) love is pictured as a star which leads the ship on the right way, so love shows the lovers their way and helps them to find back to each other.
Whenever they lost their orientation their Love helps them to find back again and it doesn't change even if both of them get lost.
The personification love's not time's fool shows that love is not influenced by time in a bad way and can notcannot altersalter just because of time.
Within his bending sickle's compass come(l. 10) is also a metaphor which means that even when you think it is over, your love hasn't changed.
Even when you are living your last days you still love somebody.
To add is the metaphor in line 12 which underlines that you hold on to love until the day you die.
So that love is strong enough to long until your death, and even further than this.
The last two lines (l. 13) are very rhetorical and ironic because we know he has written the Sonnet 116 and also other sonnets.
Furthermore he can notcannot know if any man has loved is true or not.
So it shows that Shakespeare is sure he is right and that nobody can say something differentdiffrent than this about love and how he sees it.
All in all he compares love to an unchanging, fixed mark which helps the lovers to stay in the right direction and which leads them all their liveslifes until death.
